adjectives.description: slope (comparative more slope, superlative most slope)

adverbs.description: slope (comparative more slope, superlative most slope)

entries.meaning: An area of ground that tends evenly upward or downward.
examples: I had to climb a small slope to get to the site.

entries.meaning: The degree to which a surface tends upward or downward.
examples: The road has a very sharp downward slope at that point.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The ratio of the vertical and horizontal distances between two points on a line; zero if the line is horizontal, undefined if it is vertical.
examples: The slope of this line is 0.5

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The slope of the line tangent to a curve at a given point.
examples: The slope of a parabola increases linearly with x.

entries.meaning: The angle a roof surface makes with the horizontal, expressed as a ratio of the units of vertical rise to the units of horizontal length (sometimes referred to as run).
examples: The slope of an asphalt shingle roof system should be 4:12 or greater.

entries.meaning: (vulgar, offensive, ethnic slur) A person of Chinese or other East Asian descent.

verbs.description: slope (third-person singular simple present slopes, present participle sloping, simple past and past participle sloped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To tend steadily upward or downward.
examples: The road slopes sharply down at that point.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form with a slope; to give an oblique or slanting direction to; to incline or slant.
examples: to slope the ground in a garden; Â  to slope a piece of cloth in cutting a garment

entries.meaning: (colloquial, usually followed by a preposition) To try to move surreptitiously.
examples: I sloped in through the back door, hoping my boss wouldn't see me.

entries.meaning: (military) To hold a rifle at a slope with forearm perpendicular to the body in front holding the butt, the rifle resting on the shoulder.
examples: The order was given to "slope arms".
